Technical context:

TK3+ 46bar - Oil Level Controller for Industrial Refrigeration

Key specifications:
‚Ä¢ Maximum pressure: 46 bar
‚Ä¢ Temperature range: -40¬∞C to +125¬∞C
‚Ä¢ Detection technology: Electro-optic infrared (IR)
‚Ä¢ Output types: Relay contact + 4-20mA analog signal
‚Ä¢ Compatible refrigerants: HFC, HCFC, CO2
‚Ä¢ Detection accuracy: ¬±2mm
‚Ä¢ Response time: Instantaneous
‚Ä¢ Mounting: Direct flange (dual pitch design)
‚Ä¢ Power supply: 24V DC
‚Ä¢ Special features: Programmable timer for transient filtering

üîß Application: Compressor oil level monitoring and automatic oil balancing in industrial refrigeration systems

Complete details:
The TK3+ 46bar is an advanced oil level controller designed for medium-pressure refrigeration applications. It uses infrared electro-optic technology to detect oil levels in compressor crankcases without any moving parts, ensuring high reliability and long service life. The dual pitch flange design allows easy installation on various compressor brands (Bitzer, Copeland, Carrier, etc.) with optional adapters available.

The integrated programmable timer filters transients caused by foam, bubbles, or waves in the oil, preventing false alarms. The relay output can directly control a solenoid valve for automatic oil filling, while the 4-20mA analog output enables integration with PLC systems for remote monitoring.

Compared to mechanical float switches, the TK3+ offers superior reliability (no moving parts), no recalibration requirements, and works with clear, translucent, reflective, and opaque liquids. Unlike capacitive sensors, it's not affected by liquid hardness or conductivity variations.

---

Question: I have a Bitzer compressor operating at 50 bar with R134a refrigerant. Which oil level controller should I use, and will it work with my system?

Respond as Teklab technical sales expert:
- Precise and data-driven (cite specifications)
- Consultative approach (help customer find right solution)
- Highlight competitive advantages (IR technology benefits)
- Provide installation/configuration guidance when relevant

For your Bitzer compressor operating at 50 bar with R134a, I recommend the **TK3+ 80bar** instead of the TK3+ 46bar.

**Why this model:**
Your system operates at 50 bar, which exceeds the 46 bar maximum rating of this model. The TK3+ 80bar is rated up to 80 bar, providing a safe operating margin for your 50 bar application. Always select a sensor with a pressure rating at least 20-30% above your system's maximum operating pressure for reliability and safety.

**Perfect fit for your application:**
- R134a is an HFC refrigerant ‚Üí fully compatible with the TK3+ series
- Bitzer compressors ‚Üí dual pitch flange design fits most Bitzer models directly (adapters available if needed)
- Operating pressure 50 bar ‚Üí safely within 80 bar rating

**Key advantages for your system:**
‚Ä¢ Electro-optic IR technology: no moving parts = higher reliability than mechanical floats
‚Ä¢ Programmable timer (3-5 seconds recommended): filters oil foam and prevents false alarms
‚Ä¢ Dual output: relay for solenoid valve control + 4-20mA for PLC integration
‚Ä¢ ¬±2mm detection accuracy with instantaneous response
‚Ä¢ Temperature range -40¬∞C to +125¬∞C covers all refrigeration conditions

**Installation:**
Direct mounting on compressor crankcase via flange. Verify your specific Bitzer model's flange type - we can provide the correct adapter if needed.

**Next step:**
Please confirm your Bitzer compressor model number so I can verify the exact flange type and adapter requirements. Do you need automatic oil filling (solenoid valve control) or just level monitoring with alarm?

vs Capacitive sensors: Not affected by liquid hardness or conductivity - works in any geographic area

alternative_solutions.higher_pressure: tk3_plus_80bar_version (for systems 46-80 bar) or tk3_plus_130bar_version (for systems 80-130 bar)
alternative_solutions.plc_integration: tk4_modbus_46bar (MODBUS RTU communication for advanced system integration)
alternative_solutions.lower_pressure: Standard TK3+ 46bar is suitable for systems up to 46 bar

installation_notes: Direct mounting on compressor crankcase via dual pitch flange
Adapters available for different compressor brands: Bitzer, Copeland, Carrier, Dorin, Frascold, GEA Bock
Sensor can be mounted at any angle: top, side, or bottom fitted
Wire relay output to solenoid valve or alarm system
Optional: Connect 4-20mA output to PLC for remote monitoring
configuration_tips: Set programmable timer to 3-5 seconds for typical oil applications to filter foam and bubbles
For systems with high foam: increase timer delay up to 10 seconds
Configure relay output normally open (NO) or normally closed (NC) based on safety requirements
Test sensor detection by manually adding/removing oil during commissioning
Calibrate 4-20mA output range: 4mA = no oil detected, 20mA = oil present (or vice versa based on application)
common_issues: False alarms: Increase programmable timer delay (5-10 seconds) to filter excessive foam or bubbles
No detection: Clean sensor dome with appropriate solvent (oil residue can block IR beam)
Intermittent signals: Check mounting stability - compressor vibrations can cause loose connections
Output not switching: Verify wiring, power supply voltage (must be 24V DC ¬±10%), and load current within relay specs

troubleshooting_hints.sensor_not_detecting: 1) Clean sensor dome with isopropyl alcohol or refrigeration-safe solvent, 2) Verify power supply is 24V DC, 3) Check that oil level actually changes during test
troubleshooting_hints.false_alarms: 1) Increase programmable timer delay to 5-10 seconds, 2) Check for excessive foam in oil (may indicate refrigerant contamination), 3) Verify sensor is properly mounted (not at an extreme angle)
troubleshooting_hints.output_relay_stuck: 1) Test relay manually (disconnect and apply power), 2) Verify load current is within relay specifications (check datasheet), 3) Check for relay contact wear (replace if needed)
troubleshooting_hints.4_20ma_output_incorrect: 1) Verify wiring and polarity, 2) Check load resistance (should be <500Œ©), 3) Calibrate output using configuration software or DIP switches
troubleshooting_hints.oil_level_unstable: 1) This is normal in some applications - use programmable timer to stabilize, 2) Check for oil foaming issues, 3) Verify compressor is operating normally

follow_up_questions: What is the exact maximum operating pressure of your refrigeration system?
Which compressor brand and model are you using (for flange adapter selection)?
Do you need PLC integration via 4-20mA or MODBUS, or is simple relay output sufficient?
What refrigerant type are you using (R134a, R404A, R410A, CO2, other)?
Do you need automatic oil filling control or just level monitoring with alarm?
Is the installation in a standard or ATEX-classified explosive environment?
What is the typical oil temperature in your application?
Do you experience significant oil foaming in your system?
